text: I like critics you know I want even
create me a critic hi everyone Anthony
Fantino here internet's busiest music
nerd and it's time for an album review
Meshuga colas Meshuga is a Swedish metal
band this is their seventh full-length
LP I've received a lot of requests to
talk about this LP and it's not
difficult to see why Meshuga has a
pretty heavy reputation in the metal
world they have a sound they have a
style that has influenced countless
groups over the 20-plus years they've
been releasing material and part of what
has built this Empire is consistency
they've never really put out a terrible
record a terrible record however they've
never really ventured that far outside
of what has been proven to work for them
almost every studio album these guys
have released has been a very slight
variation on the same theme endlessly
perfecting one single approach Jen's
Kidman's vocals used to be a little bit
more intelligible on the band's older
stuff of course over the years with new
technology the group's heaviness factor
has increased but I gotta say on this
new LP it's pretty much Meshuga as usual
you know not much for me to report in
terms of what this album really offers
to to longtime fans
sorry to disappoint the people who were
asking me to review this but I think
just constant comparisons to every
single other LP Meshuga has released
before this one would be kind of like
splitting hairs I'm not trying to say
there's not differences between this LP
and others that this band is put out and
we will get into a few of them later but
I'd much rather focus on maybe trying to
turn people on to this group so if this
is the first time you're running into
Meshuga or you've been curious about
them you're in for a very heavy treat
machetes world pretty much
around the Rif which is nothing entirely
new but the way the group approaches
this that's what sets them apart first
it's the guitar tone that these guys put
out which is just like I said earlier
been a result of constantly perfecting
trying this one thing making it bigger
making it better making a heavy hear the
sound is a little more commonplace than
it used to be but it's mostly because so
many groups try to copycat this style
the chugs that Meshuga pushes out there
are so thick they're so bassy
and when they Bend a string they really
let it ring out it gives off this sound
like one oh it's so guttural it's so
thick and deep and mechanical it sounds
like something being dismantled or
destroyed or crushed the guitars on this
LP are basically the size of the
explosions in like a Michael Bay film
the opener alone I am Colossus just
gives me this image of a giant robot
demon roaring out with fire and molten
lava pouring past its jaws and all of
the riffs are pretty much emphasizing
just a really heavy groove and
Michigan's grooves are really how they
define themselves the group is always
looking for some kind of odd time
signature to play in or just seeking
some kind of way to take a rhythm take a
groove and just diddle it just throw it
off and helping this out are the drums
though the guitars on a Meshuga record
are incredibly important I feel like in
a way the guitars are there to kind of
emphasize all the awesome stuff the
drums are doing to me the drums usually
steal the show on a Meshuga LP and this
is no different the beats the rhythms
are ever-changing always improvising
lots of tasteful fills the drum sound
fantastic whether they're doing
something slow and primal like behind
the Sun or kind of speeding things up
and throw in a double bass drum in there
like on the demons name I am it
immediately a bigger fan of the slower
tracks though where the band really hits
just very sludgy molasses speed tempos
and they let those guitars wring out and
get really heavy they just feel
gargantuan on those tracks now with all
these guitars and drums and and Kidman's
kind of mid-range growl covering every
single one of these songs Meshuga kind
of toys with the foundation of of what
sort of groove metal new metal jump the
[ __ ] riffs but with some fantastic
drumming some really interesting to tar
tone a lot of heaviness and technical
ability Meshuga is a metal band that
puts out energetic tracks with heavy
riffs that appeal beyond the aggression
and actually make this sound this style
something worth giving a second chance
if you've already kind of written it off
it's got a lot of virtuosity and though
it is technical music it doesn't come
across as difficult because Meshuga
pumps these grooves out so naturally
with so much ease with so much energy
it's just easy to get into the track and
maybe not even feel like you're
listening to something that is all that
complex but I did not come here to just
simply praise the cell P because I do
have some issues with it though there
are some variations in speed on this
album there's not really many variations
in intensity or volume nearly every song
here kind of shoots for the same level
of those two things the last track is a
lone guitar instrumental that's it's
very soft very gentle kind of pretty but
it's it's a little too late though there
are some highlights on here that get me
going break those bones maro dum yuge
listening to this LP all the way through
can be a little bit of a drag especially
since the faster tracks on here feel a
little bit too mechanical for me to to
really get into the grooves to really
feel them which is funny because that's
not an issue
I had with faster tracks from the band's
previous material I definitely did not
feel that way on chaos fear and another
issue I'm kind of having is the guitar
solos I know the guitar solos have never
been a primary focus in meshuggaas music
especially since these days the riffs
have taken so much precedent but there
are a lot of times on this LP where I
wish the guitars would change things up
at least a little bit and attempt to do
something that is that is just as
technical as the drums like the track
behind the Sun toward the beginning of
the song the guitars are just kind of
playing this very lazy sort of
atmospheric lead I'm not even sure what
it is it's just kind of there to add
another sound and toward the end of the
track that's very kind of blurry and and
boring guitar solo comes in and just
does not really add that much and it's
it's mixed solo it's buried I can barely
make it out and the guitar solo toward
the end of the demon's name is is not
good oh man it's just tapping and it
sounds like it's tapping at it at a
completely different tempo it just kind
of feels like tapping just a half
tapping on the album because it sounds
technical on on the surface but there's
not really an interesting tap pattern or
anything going on with the solo so as
much as I do like the riffs on this
thing the guitars really don't do much
more than that to me chaos fear and
destroy a race improve had way better
solos the solo on the opener to chaos
sphere is still one of the weirdest
solos I've heard on a metal record and
as far as style and variation goes
throughout an entire album catch 33 had
way more to offer so overall I did think
this was a likeable LP but it will not
be going down as one of my favorites in
the Meshuga discography I'm kind of
feeling a light too decent 6 on this
thing but what do you guys think of it
do you love it
do you hate it why and what should I
review next
Anthony Fantana Meshuga colos forever
[Music]
